description:
From the publisher:
Tangram is a classic seven-piece dissection puzzle from China. In Tangram Race, each player has a set of tangram pieces. Pick a task card randomly and try to form the shape shown in the card. The first player to do so gets the card, and the first player to collect five task cards, wins the game! 
With three difficulty levels, Tangram Race is suitable for both beginners and advanced players. The game includes 200 tasks and solutions.

Wolf im Schafspelz is a fast-paced dice game in which you must quickly evaluate the roll of the dice and toss the right card in the right box. The faster you are, the more points you score – assuming you're correct, of course.

In the basic game, each player holds a wool card and the two halves of the box are laid face-up on the table, one showing a sheep in the bottom and the other a wolf. Players roll five or seven animal dice, depending on the number of players, then they try to scan the dice quickly to see which animal group – the sheep or wolves – are in the majority so that they can through their wool card in that box. Players who do so score 0-3 chips, depending on the number of players and how quickly they threw in their card; anyone tossing in the wrong box loses one chip. The first player to collect ten chips wins.

In the advanced game, a spice/wool die is rolled with the animal dice, and players need to throw the appropriate card – spice or wool – into the appropriate box. In the elite game, a blue animal die comes into play. If the blue animal die is part of the sheep/wolf majority, then game play is identical to the advanced game for that round; if not, then players must throw the symbol not showing on the spice/wool die into the right box.

One final variant can be used with all three levels of play: When the sheep are in the majority, those who score in the round receive a sheep chip; when the wolves are ascendant, they receive a wolf chip. The winner is the first player to collect both five sheep chips and five wolf chips.

From publisher:

Aliens vs Boy Scouts (Prepared? Always be prepared!) is a dynamic game for a large group of friends. Two teams are at a standoff: the aliens steal the boy scouts during the “night” phase of the game, and the boy scouts vote to eliminate one player during each of the “day” phases in an attempt to neutralize the aliens. The game develops diplomatic skills as well as analytical and deductive thinking. Based on the widely known game Mafia, Aliens vs. Boy Scouts offers a different plot together with expanded gaming abilities. The game has a number of advantages over its free print-n-play prototype:

- originally illustrated cards 
- new gaming elements: “objects” and “events”
- a different environment: one without murder and criminal activity 
- other useful materials: a referee chart and voting tokens

Dégage is a semi-cooperative card game that takes on the theme of the Tunisian Jasmine Revolution (or more aptly named The Revolution for Dignity by the Tunisians.  The goal is for the players to successfully eliminate the Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali and his clique mafia.  The game revolves around these seven Zaba members; each have a specific power related to their personality that benefits them, but not those in the general population.  These are known as character "defects" in the game.  These "defects" are represented by various icons on the cards and indicate what "pressue" can be used to "eliminate" the character.  Once players line up enough cards with the matching icons for a character, the character is removed.  The person who dethrones the seventh character is the winner.  If the 7 characters are not removed before the end of the game, all players have lost.

Gitterrätsel! Junior is the kid's version of GitterrÃ¤tsel!.

Rotating the game board reveals a sequence of images, a word or an image in an open field of the board edge is visible. Whoever first discovers the corect sequence of pictures and letters on the board is the winner.  Opponents compete to discover the hidden word first corresponding to the picture and mark it with tiles. However, if another player finds a word that is marked by another opponent's tiles than that opponent looses the word.  Whoever has the most at the end pieces on the game board wins!  This game promotes playful speed and concentration.
A collectable version of the classic game Monopoly. This edition comes in the form of a die-cast semi-tractor trailer truck. The trailer opens to reveal a miniature version of the standard game.

In his turn player draws a card and announce the title and artist of song. Players then bet on your success in the interpretation of the work. Finally, you push your bellowing, and each win or lose the bet.

Your goal is to be the first to have set up your herd of 10 cows, calves and bulls of the same color.
But beware! Your opponents are ruthless and will not hesitate to send you the worst nasties like drought, mad cow etc.

In his turn player play a card for his herd or nasty card for his opponent.

Player who set up his herd first avoiding the nasty cards is the winner.

Spodd is a two player game with a twist for the Series: Shibumi game system.

Equipment: the 4x4 Shibumi board, balls in two colors. The board is rotated 45 degrees to have clearly seven columns with varying number of balls (1-3-5-7-5-3-1 on the surface of the Shibumi pyramid).

Rules: the board starts with two red balls placed in the left and right corner holes. Two players, White and Black, take turns placing one ball of each color adjacent to each other. The balls can be placed on board holes or on top of 2x2 platforms of existing balls. You can place a ball on a hole and the other on a platform, as long as they touch each other.

Aim: without the left and right corner holes there are five columns with an odd number of balls on the pyramid surface (3-5-7-5-3). When the pyramid is complete, the player with the most visible balls in a column wins that column. The winner is the player who has won at least 3 columns.

Variant for expert players: players score one point when they have conquered a column composed by three balls, two points for a five balls column and three points for the seven balls column. The winner is the player with the highest score.

Note: the game has an odd number of columns composed by an odd number of balls. Ties are not possible.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

vintage roll dice and move game from 1941;
Players start at the coast of South America and "sails" west. 
The target is being the first to Sail to the Tonga Isles in one piece and find the great Pirate treasure, all the while avoiding bad weather, pirates, coral reefs and other dangers along the way.

There is only one rather swirly route that takes you across the pacific oceans over towards Australia and The target Tonga Isles (passing Islands and groups like Tahiti, Baker Island, Gilbert Isle, St Cruz & Fidji) and if you hit certain spots/numbers along the travel, actions are taken according to rulesheet.

In the card-driven board game Rialto, the goal is to earn the most victory points (VPs), which are awarded for a variety of things. The game board displays the six districts of Venice, and players earn VPs for placing council members into these, for building bridges and placing gondolas to connect the districts with one another, and for building advantageous buildings.

The game is played over six rounds, with each round consisting of three phases:

1. Acquire cards: Each player takes a set of cards.
2. Play cards: Players use cards to perform certain actions.
3. Activate buildings: Players may take advantage of their buildings and use their powers.

In phase 1, sets of eight cards are displayed (with six cards face-up and two face-down). Each player takes one set, then reduces his hand to seven cards. A card shows one of six specific characters (Architect, Merchant, etc.) or is a wild card.

Phase 2 consists of six sub-phases in a fixed order, one for each character. In each sub-phase, players choose whether or not to play one or more cards of that specific character. Each card allows them to perfom that character's action, for example:


     Take one piece of gold for each Merchant card you play.
     Place one council member into the current district for each Council card you play.
     Take a building with a value equal to or lower than the number of Architect cards played. The higher its value, the better its function.


Whoever plays the most cards in each such sub-phase receives a bonus of one free action of that type. In case of a tie, whoever is farthest along the "Doge" bar gets the bonus – and of course to advance on the Doge bar, players need to play Doge cards.

Finally, in phase 3, players may take advantage of their buildings. For each piece of gold paid, a player may use one of his building's ability.

Players collect VPs both during the game – from special buildings and by building bridges between districts – and at the end of it – for majorities of council members in each district. The value of each district evolves during the game: Each district is adjacent to four other ones, and at the end of the game, they will be connected either via bridges or gondolas. A bridge increases the value of the adjacent districts by 3-6 victory points, whereas a gondola increases this value by 1 point. The player with the most council members in a district earns VPs equal to the district's total value, the player with the secondmost council members earns half this value, and so on. While it's important to establish majorities in the districts, it's also crucial to control their values by cleverly placing those bridges and gondolas.

Vanquish Sauron, destroy the Ring and save Middle Earth ... in twenty minutes!

Inspired by Knizia's best selling board game about Tolkien's opus, this condensed cooperative dicefest takes you and your band of hobbits in a quest to bring the Ring to Mount Doom.

In the game, players must help each other avoid and fight the dangers lurking in Middle Earth. Along the way, the players will pick up resources and gifts which they will record on their hobbit boards using 6-sided dice as counters. On a typical turn, a player will roll the event die to determine how a scenario advances --- will he pick up a resource or must he deal with a misfortune that would bring the Fellowship closer to Sauron's corrupting influence?

Game Components:

1 corruption tracking board
7 scenario boards
1 gandalf/elven gifts resource board
4 hobbit pawns
4 hobbit boards
6-sided dice for counters
1 Sauron pawn
1 ring token
4 resource dice (blue)
1 corruption die (white)
1 gray event die
1 red event die
30 cube markers
3 ‘sun’ life tokens
3 ‘heart’ life tokens
4 ‘ring’ life tokens

This free print and play game can only be distributed for non-commercial purposes.

Cosmic Express is a quick-playing version of Fantasy Flight Games' extremely awesome Cosmic Encounter. It takes the elements of Cosmic Encounter that make it so fantastic (negotiating, backstabbing, variable alien powers, alliances) and tries to deliver it in a half hour playing time, and with far less components than the original.

The game replaces Encounter Cards with Encounter Dice, of which a player only has one at any given time. When having an Encounter, players can choose to Fight (hold the die in their fist) or Negotiate (keep their fist empty). The classic Prisoner's Dilemma outcomes apply, with mutually fighting players rolling their dice to determine a winner.

The game is completely free to print and play, and uses no artwork from Fantasy Flight Games. It is designed as a tribute to on of my favourite games of all time and as a thank-you to the BGG community, who has given me so much enjoyment and help in the last year.

Corporation$ is a modern economic game. Create ultimate wealth by building corporations that dominate their industries and test your  investment skills by choosing which corporations to buy stock in.  Expand your influence by merging corporations and starting new corporations in new industries. But be careful or you may over-extend and find yourself with no cash to keep your corporations running and then lose your influence!

Players start by choosing an industry to launch their corporation. Then they can buy stock in their corporation, increase the corporations market share, and even merge even merge with other corporations. The player has to decide which strategy will work to their benefit. Should they buy more stocks, increase their market share, or merge with other corporations.

During regular gameplay, players receive revenue from their corporations, pay expenses, buy and sell stocks, buy marketshare in the auction phase, or merge with other corporations.

The player with the most net worth at the end of the game wins!

With Corporation$ you must balance your ambitious goals of becoming the wealthiest billionaire while managing the growing needs of your corporations.  Do it poorly and count yourself one of the many who have tried and failed.  Do it well and you may become the greatest wealth-generating businessman and investor of all time!  At least within the world of the game called Corporation$.

Blood on the Alma was released in Line of Fire Magazine # 13, "Blood on the Alma" is a 2-3 player game recreating the 1854 Battle of the Alma River at the brigade level. Each unit is represented by a stack of step counters that modifies attack strength.  Each army plays differently-- the French have a more traditional sequence of play, their allies the British are activated by chit pull, and the outnumbered Russians must contend with morale checks while dealing with phases that are scattered throughout allied phases.  The Russians have a terrain advantage which they historically squandered; the allies possessed a technological advantage in the Minie Rifle, but due to poor communication, it was not used by the British until late in the battle, when it turned the tide decisively.  Combat is resolved by comparing modifiers to defense rolls, and the type of attacking unit determines the available outcomes.  A number of factors, including victory for each side, are tied to and fluctuate with a single track, creating a sense of momentum and narrative.

Requires:  Standard 52 card poker deck with 2 jokers.

Theme
Grab your friends and go rafting down the river!  Whirlpools will send you for a spin!  Be the best rapid wrangler to win!

Gameplay
Setup
Shuffle the deck.

Each player draws 10 cards minus how many players there are.  (ex. 4 players, draw 6 cards).  The remaining cards are placed in the middle and are known as the Pile.

Turn Order
Turn Order
Start Oour Turn
a) Draw a card from the Pile…
b) Or, place 1 Jack, Queen, or King back into the bottom of the Pile to draw 2, 3, or 4 cards respectively.

Build a Raft
2) Place cards down on the table to start building rafts.  You can swap cards in and out of your hand and onto rafts to improve the point totals of rafts.

End Your Turn
a) Play an Ace card…
b) Or, play a Joker card…
c) Or, End your turn.

What is a Raft
Building a Raft:  Every raft that has 4 numerically consecutive cards and a face card on top is considered a complete raft.  You may continue to improve complete rafts.  Card suits do not matter.

Friendly Competition
Playing an Ace Card:  This is called a Whirlpool.  Say "Whirlpool", show the players your Ace, and put the ace into the deck.  Every player places their hand into the deck.  Shuffle the deck and draw the same number of cards you had before the Whirlpool (ex. if you put 6 cards into the deck because of the Whirlpool, draw 6 new cards).

Playing a Joker Card:  This is called "Let's go down the river".  Say "Let's go down the river", show the players your Joker, and put the joker at the bottom of the deck.  Each player takes all of their incomplete rafts and puts them back into the deck.  Shuffle the deck.  Each player gathers all of their complete rafts and puts them aside to now be counted as points.  These rafts are no longer in play.

Progress
Ending the Round:  The round ends when a player is unable to draw cards from the Pile.  The player with the highest point total wins that round.

Calculating Points:  Points are calculated by adding up the number cards into a total.  Then, add the face value cards into the total.  Jacks are worth 1, Queens are 3, and Kings are 5 additional points.

Goal
Have the highest point total at the end of 3 rounds.

The game consists of 31 tiles that will form the oval game board, 6 "memo" tiles with one color per side, 6 pawns and a die with six faces. When the game starts forming a path with 31 tiles oval course that will be different for each game. Tiles "memo", which have color front / back, are placed in the center of the table so as to show the four possible colors. Each player picks a color pawn.

In turn, the active player rolls the dice. If it's six, he misses a turn. If it's between 1 and 5, it has the choice between:
1: re-roll, but if it's 6 or the same number, it passes.
2: he moves his pawn to a number of dice equal to the tile.

The course ends with the tile "Peasant Confederation" and the first player to reach this tile is declared "Grand Winner".

Zug um Zug: Deutschland is a stand-alone game in the Game: Ticket to Ride (Official) series. Over the course of the game, players collect cards in order to then claim routes on the game board between two cities. Ideally the players create a network of routes that connect the cities showing on their secret ticket cards. Players score points both for claiming routes and for completing tickets, with incomplete tickets counting against a player's score. Whoever has the most points at the end of the game wins.

Zug um Zug: Deutschland, published solely for the German and Austrian market, consists of the same map as Ticket to Ride: MÃ¤rklin – with the game now set at the turn of the 20th century – but the game does not include the passenger mechanism from Märklin in which players scored additional points by moving passengers from city to city. In addition, the numbers of destination tickets and train cards differ slightly between the two games.

Part of Ticket to Ride series.

Interesting party game. 24 cards all depict pictures of a cat, in eight sets of three identical pictures. Having said that there are eight sets of three, the pictures are all fairly similar. So good observation will be needed.

Place all the cards around a room. Each participating guest must look at the pictures during the party and make their observations. The first one to hand in all eight 'versions' of the pictures, wins.

A compilation of games includes rule sets for Checkers and Tic-Tac-Toe, plus several other games:

Meet in the Middle: One player uses a "mama" animal, the other uses a "baby" animal.  They start at opposite ends of the board and alternate die rolls until the two animals meet.

Home Sweet Home: All of the animals are divided among the players.  In turn, each player rolls the die and puts the number of animals rolled onto the game board.  The winner is the person who gets all of their animals on first.

Suppertime!: Players get two animals and have to move them to the barn.  On each turn, the player rolls one die and can split the movement between the two animals in any manner. Landing on a space occupied by another animal sends that animal back to the closest unoccupied colored space.  The first player to get both of their animals to the barn wins.

Barnyard Chase: Each player selects an animal and places it on the opposite diagonal corners of the included checkerboard.  In turn, players roll the die and move clockwise around the board.  First player to pass the other wins.

"Brain" in English
There is a mathematical or linquistical exercise in one side of the card and answer in another side of the card.

In his turn player solves the exercise.
If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

"German History" in English
There is a 2 or 3 questions in one side of the card and 4 variants for each question and answers/information in another side of the card.

In his turn player reads the question and choose the variant. If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

"Words" in English
There is a 2 or 3 questions in one side of the card and variants for each question and answers/information in another side of the card.

In his turn player reads the question and choose the variant. If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

"Intelligence Training" in English
There is exercise in one side of the card and variants and answer in another side of the card.

In his turn player tries tosolve the exercise. If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

"Puzzle" in English
There is a puzzle in one side of the card and answer in another side of the card.

In his turn player need to solve the puzzle. If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

Quizzard game for younger audiance where you not only have to be right, you have to be fast. The heart of the game is an electronic buzzer device that records who will answer the question first. Up to 6 players have this buzzer pad in front of them and the first one who hits the button gets to answer. However, you can lose points for incorrect answers so before you hit the button you'd better know the answer.

The game was played much like Trivial Pursuit, running in a circular motion with the players collecting coloured counters upon answering various questions or completing a particular task. The colour coding defined which question would be asked and the reward for a right answer was one of the tokens. A completed set of tokens meant the player could then progress into the center circle and complete the game.

This is a light war game based on two teams of kids facing off in a game of capture the flag.  Their weapon of choice: Pine Cones.  In this simultaneous action selection game, out think your opponents by choosing the best strategy.  Each turn, you get to choose two actions in secret and then they are resolved in player order. You can move, gather pine cones, throw pine cones, or rest to recover damage.

Do you rush for the flag, or gather an armful of pine cones before you advance?  Do you attack from a safe distance or close in for the knockout blow?  There is no player elimination, but any player taking too much damage misses turns until he's rested enough to return to the game.

The Metre Litre Gram Game is the fun way to learn metric.

The game consists of a playing board, six player tokens, two dice, five decks of cards (metre, litre, gram, chance, and exam), a rule sheet and a sheet that explains the metric system.

The path on the board is in the shape of the letter m, which stands for metre.  The left leg has metre questions, the middle section has litre and temperature questions, and the right leg has gram questions.  After rolling the dice the player takes the larger of the two dice and moves their token forward and takes a question card from the appropriate stack.  If the player answers the question correctly their token remains on that square.  If the player is incorrect the player moves backwards the smaller number of spaces.  If the player rolls doubles their token is moved forward the total of the two dice, and moves backwards the distance indicated on one die in the case of an incorrect answer. If the player lands on a square the same colour as their token, a chance card is drawn.  On some spaces an exam card is drawn.  A player cannot move again until an exam question is answered correctly. The first player to travel the board wins.

Game uses double nine dominoes and has an electronic Chicken Coop hub.  Players start with 7, 9, or 11 dominoes depending on the number playing.  The first player who has a double nine plays it in the center hub, and the next six dominoes fill in the spaces around the hub to form the chicken legs (if a player cannot match a nine, they draw and play or pass).  After that, players match domino ends until a double is played.

When a double is played, the player presses the hub and normal play is suspended until three chicken "toes" are played.  The next three dominoes must match the double and are played under the double, one angled to the left, one in the center and one angled to the right (to form the chicken foot).  Players who cannot match can draw and play the match, or they must pass.  Play continues until the three toes are completed and normal play resumes either on the chicken toes or any of the chicken legs.

Play ends when a player plays their last domino or the game is blocked (because no plays can be made and the "chicken yard" (spare dominoes) is exhausted.  The player who gets rid of their dominoes scores 0.  The other players count their pips on their remaining dominoes to get their score.  A new round then begins. After 10 rounds, player with the lowest score wins.

A Mille Bornes variant with animals in much the same way as its predecessor. Here are ranging animals instead of kilometers!

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must form the sentences with the words on the cards.

The goal is to make sentences with these words. Since we Dujardin, add a few cards of attack and defense. The fire becomes red misspelling, and the green light a dictionary.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by exposing the maximum cards in as many rounds as possible (there are 12 series: the beginnings, the Patriarchs, Moses, To the promised land, the time of the Kingdom, the time exile, renewal, a new prophet, Jesus' encounters, the messages of Jesus, the passion, the early Christians). Each set contains 6 cards.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

Per Magellan's website: "Jackal" is a great strategy game, originating from the 70's MSU (Moscow State University), best-selling and simply the best game of the 2012. You take the command of the adventurous pirates, who disembark on the island searching for the treasure. The goal is to find gold and bring it to your ship. The island consists of tiles, each with different stuff: you can find fort, cannon, meet a crocodile, find a message bottle or dig one of the Captain Jackal's treasures.

"Jackal. Treasure island" consists of basic version and addition. Empty tiles (with meadows) were removed from the basic versions and changed for tiles with new adventures. Rules are uniform, plus there are FAQ included and also a pirate swearing vocabulary. There is a special frame for the island now, put together like puzzle - it helps your map to look more accurate on the table."

Adds some new rules, new tiles, new accessories such as boat, cannonballs, big gold coin. New tiles have different effects, and it is possible to use them  instead of no effect tiles from basic jackal, or together to create big island to discover. Much more variants of islands with this extension.

The game of Bescherelle is a game designed for fun around the traps and conjugations of the French language.

TO goal is to conjugate a verb or answer a question in French.
Players may get magical potions to transform into superheroes and defence against attacks from your opponents!

Award-winning and recommended by the Ministry of Culture and Communication of France.

The game includes 5000 questions on French/foreign literature and the French language.  It plays like 'snake and ladders', without shortcuts, though.

The board consists of several squares with different topics like: works, authors, expression, citations, parenthesis etc.
Also some special square like:

    Bomb Box: Opponents choose the theme. If the player answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
    Boom Box: The player chooses the theme. If he answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
    Box blank page: Player advances with as many questions indicated on card if he answered said questions correctly.


The winner is the first to be arriving on the "Red and Black" final square and who has also responded right to three questions from a single trivia card.

Players are journalists and write a newspaper

By answering questions correctly, player draws a cards in the pocket to fill the place on his newspaper. The first player to have completed his newspaper is the winner.

Using the plate divided into several zones, you spin the arrow, and you pull the card corresponding to the area where the arrow is stopped.

There are several type of cards:
- INTERVIEW is a collective issue, the first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- INTERVIEW PHOTO is a collective issue, but the question is about the photo visible to all players. The first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- EXPERT is an individual matter. The player whose turn is must answer and draws a card in the pouch for good responders.
- OPPORTUNITY allows to draw a card from the pocket, without having to answer a question.
- BAD LUCK forced the player to deliver one of his cards in the pocket.
- SCOOP is to get a card in an opponent's cards.
- INTERNET cards are optional, as they require an internet connection, to monitor response. If used, they are incorporated in the stack of cards interview.

Though the real history of how the Old World powers spread their influence and came to dominate the USA will never be known, American Illuminati gives you the opportunity to demonstrate how, as the leader of one of these old world dynasties, you would have accomplished the feat.

You will become the leader of an ancient Illuminati faction. Your objective is to infiltrate agents into the newly forming United States in order to exert control over the state governments. The more states you control, the greater your power in the federal government. The more control you have in the federal government the more power you have to dominate the world.

AI is a Euro-style board game that plays equally well with 2, 3 or 4 players. The mechanics are simple enough that you can teach most anyone to play, though strategic players are much more likely to win.

Each player is attempting to place agents into the newly forming USA. The more states your faction controls during the four major turning points in 19th century US history, the more conspiracy cards you will draw. Conspiracy cards can be used to gain advantages during the game but are also how you win the game.The Conspiracy Deck mimics a standard deck of playing cards though all the suites are different to fit the Illuminati theme. Throughout the game you are secretly attempting to form the best Poker hand (what's more American than Poker?) with your Conspiracy Cards while playing your Action Cards to maximum advantage.

Magnetic game in which the purpose is to obtain a capital superior to that of the opponents by extracting the most amount of oil.

Players are represented by 4 Disney characters who try to get rich in this Monopoly style game with a cute oil rig miniature which moves due to a magnet secretly located under the board whenever the players choose to dig for oil in the right spot.

Contents: Board with a trigger tied to 3 magnets located underneath, 4 Disney characters, banknotes, 8 building concession cards, 36 right to drill cards, oil deposits plastic pawns in 2 colors, magnetic oil rig miniature, 2 dice, rules.

A cooperative deck building game of vigilante heroism.

You won't see Crime City on any map, but that's how people have come to know your hometown. Sadists, Anarchists, the Mafia, each carving out portions of the city they call their own. Hundreds of innocent bystanders caught up every day in their turf wars, or held under their oppressive thumbs. Precious few have the time, the money, the guts, or the wherewithal to do anything about it. You're one of those few... of course it means you'll have to give up that happy home life, or that cushy job. The newspaper paints vigilantism in a negative light - you'd be viewed by the community as a monster. But your city bleeds... the city bleeds and it calls your name. Will you answer?

You're a vigilante hero, one of the few in Crime City who have come together to put an end to the reign of terror the city's been trapped under. Banding together, you'll fight through a swath of henchmen in order to find and defeat one or more Arch Villains. But to get stronger as a hero, you'll have to neglect some parts of your Alter Ego life - your family, your job, or your community. Which aspect of your Alter Ego life will you neglect?

Legacy: Gears of Time is a strategic card game, mechanically rooted in its time travel theme. Players each play cards from their own hand, draw from a central draw pile, move and play technologies on a single timeline, while placing their influence cubes on existing technologies.

Legacy is played on a timeline that grows at the end of each of 4 rounds. Players take turns during a round consisting of 3 actions each. During each turn, you may travel back in time, play a technology card from your hand, influence an existing technology, or draw two cards (keeping only one).

As you travel back in time, Technologies are played from your hand by paying their discard cost. Any technologies you play generate influence for you automatically.

Having more influence than your opponents is the key to claiming rewards for a technology! At the end of each round, rewards are given for each technology and its dependencies. One Influence cube from each technology will come off at the end of each round, forming your influence pool to be used in future rounds to influence existing technologies. Keep in mind, a technology is only considered successful if all of its dependencies exist previously on the timeline.

Since there are several copies of each technology, you may be able to preempt and eliminate an existing copy by playing yours earlier in the timeline!  Be sure there is room for your new technology, though; each time-frame has a capacity equal to it's distance from the present.

There are also a few rare but powerful Fate cards, each allowing you to break the rules in interesting ways. Fate cards have no discard cost and don't require an action to be played.

By strategically influencing existing technologies, adapting to your opponents actions, and carefully choosing when to go further back in time, you will find yourself victorious over your rivals! History remains intact until the Ancient Machine demands you return to the past to rebuild history, and your Legacy, once more.

Summary:

     4 Rounds
     4 Turns per Round
     3 Actions per Turn (any mix of the following):
         Travel back in Time
         Play a Technology card
         Influence an existing Technology
         Draw two cards (keep one)

The mythical realm of Hyperborea was ruled by an ancient civilization that used magical crystals as their main source of energy. With time, the Hyperboreans became greedy, and their search for power in the deep made the crystals unstable, causing earthquakes, mutations, droughts and floods. Hyperboreans just dug deeper, and only a few wise mages, foreseeing the inevitable, built an unbreakable magical barrier. When the unharnessed magical energy was unleashed from the deep, the Hyperborean civilization was destroyed in a single day, only the magical barrier preventing the disappearance of life from the whole land. The survivors living in the small outposts outside Hyperborea were now sealed out by the barrier. The knowledge of crystals was declared forbidden it was because too dangerous, or simply forgotten.

Over centuries, six rival realms were born from the ashes of the Hyperborean civilization: the militarist Red Duchy; the Emerald Kingdom and its death-delivering archers; the Purple Matriarchy fanatically worshipping the goddess of life; the skilled diplomats and merchants of the Golden Barony; the Coral Throne with its efficiently organized society and finally the secluded and enigmatic Celestial Reign.

The fragile peace between the different realms was not intended to last. One day, the magical barrier suddenly collapsed. A whole new land stood in front of the six kingdoms, still haunted by the old Hyperboreans turned into harmless but ominous ghosts, full of ruins to discover and cities to explore. Each realm is now sending its best warriors and explorers to Hyperborea in order to achieve dominance over their rivals, but which will prevail? Brutal strength or deep understanding of science? The discovery of valuable artifacts in the lost ruins or the retaking of long, lost cities? Only you, as the leader of one of the factions, can lead your people to the ultimate dominance over Hyperborea!

Set in a mythical land of the same name, Hyperborea is a light civilization game for 2 to 6 players that takes 20-25 minutes per player. The game begins at the time when the magic barrier protecting access to the mythical continent of Hyperborea suddenly falls.

Each player takes the role of the leader of a small kingdom situated just outside the now open to be conquered and explored land. Her kingdom has limited knowledge of housing, trade, movement, warfare, research, and growth, but new and exciting powers are hidden in Hyperborea. During the game, this kingdom will grow in numbers and raise armies, extend its territory, explore and conquer, learn new technologies, etc...

The game's main mechanism, which can be described as "bag-building", involves you building a pool of "civilicubes". Each cube represents specializations for your kingdom: war, trade, movement, building, knowledge, growth. Grey cubes represent corruption and waste, and players will acquire them by developing new technologies. (Power corrupts by its own definition, and the more complex a society becomes, the more waste it generates.) Each turn, players draw three random cubes from their bags, then use them to activate knowledge (technologies) they own.

Objective: be the first to finish 1050 km
 - moving by turn -
1 each player throws 3 dice - a 4 gives you a car, a 2 a chauffeur; you need BOTH
2 '5' let you move forward one space (50 km), '1' two spaces (100 km) 
remarks: 
published during 1920's
meeples: pewter cars

Object of the game is to build his own house by answering the questions for rooms.

Playing the game
Using the dice, each player goes through the corridors of the house.
In choosing his route, he stops at:
- A room: In answering the corresponding question, he wins the card with the room to place it on his house.
- A box 'Forum': He asks the room of their choice to other players and hope they do not know the answer!
- A box 'Mission': He draws a card and runs Mission
- A box 'Bingo': He went into the room of his choice. If he answers the question, he won three-piece card, otherwise he loses 2!
- A secret passage. It uses this shortcut to quickly move from one floor to another house.

Who builds up his house first wins the game.

A "race game" placed in the ancient Roman Empire. Each player leads an expedition along the "Amber Road" to gain worthy resources along the travel.

Moving along the Road consumes resources such as water, food, etc. The first thing an expedition needs to do is fill up its supplies. While still in the starting area, a player may take up to four resource tokens and/or coins; he may stay as long in this starting area and take resources as he wants. When a player thinks he has enough for the journey, he takes off.
In a turn, a player has three options: spend two tokens and move one step for each ox you have; move one step without spending tokens; or remain where he is.
If a player moves to a new mapboard, he has to roll the stick beforehand to see which board is placed. After this each player has the option to place a village marker.
On each map section the terrain changes; on a number of special places a player may perform different useful tasks, such as refilling his supply of water, food or acquire an ox.

Villages are useful to buy supplies. Markers that show the 'pax' side consider the village to be friendly, however, when the village is hostile, it attacks the expedition. All oxes and scout then are placed in the bag together with three neutral green tokens. Two tokens drawn from the bag are considered lost.
If the village is friendly, the stick is rolled. The dots shown is the number of resource tokens a player gets for each silver coin in this village.
When the first player reaches the end of the road by exact count, he wins.

Stacket! is a game of placing uniquely shaped wooden pieces in an ever increasing tower.  Players seek to keep the tower stable after adding a piece while creating ever more difficult challenges for the next player to do the same.

The basic set contains 1 base (starting) piece, 24 additional wooden pieces and a rules sheet in a convenient carrying case.

Stacket! shares a number of mechanics with other block-stacking games such as Bandu, Animal Upon Animal, Blockhead! and Jenga.  It is distinct from these other games insofar as each piece placement much touch the previous piece and there is no piece duplication in the common pool.  As a result, Stacket! forces players to interact directly on the structure itself and it allows players to use position as well as orientation and weight as a constrain on their opponent's future choices.  The dynamics of gameplay which arise from these unique features make it likely that Stacket! will appeal to an audience that is slightly more aggressive and directly competitive. But like each of the other games in the genre, it appeals to any audience that enjoys creative challenges balancing blocks with a degree of strategy.

Optional rules for Stacket! allow players to score points based upon how many existing pieces a new pieces touches when it is placed.  Stacket! also has a rules variant for multi-set competition.

In Flag Frenzy!, players try to match flags on cards in their hands with flags on the table, emptying their personal card deck before anyone else can.

Flag Frenzy! consists of 49 flag cards and 8 continent cards (two each of Europe, Africa, Asia and the Americas); each flag card shows eight flags, and any two flag cards have exactly one flag in common, similar to the cards in Catch the Match and Spot It!

Game play differs from those titles, however, as two cards are placed face-up on the table at the start of play while the remainder of the deck is distributed evenly among the players. All players take two cards in hand, then everyone simultaneously tries to play onto the face-up cards by spotting the matching flag and giving its country's name when playing the card. With a continent card, the player has to name a flag on the continent being played.

After playing one or two cards, the player refills her hand. The first player to play all of the cards in her deck wins.

Players form the words on the Scrabble-like game board and try to lead the word path to the central cross of the board.

Players start from their own corners.
In his turn player must use the last letter of the word already on the board and forms the new word starting with this letter.
There are also possibilities to capture opponents' letters.

The player who succeeds first to reach to the central cross, thanks to the progress of his words must forms a last word and wins the game.

Each player has 6 pieces. Two value 1, two value 2 & two value 3.
They place 1 of these in each of the six sports (Running, Swimming, Javelin, Pole Vault, Rowing & Show Jumping).
A die (D3) is rolled & multiplied by the value of the piece to determine how far or high they have managed. This is repeated until the event is complete & Gold, Silver & Bronze are awarded appropriately. Some events may require particular values to be attained in order to continue.
Once all 6 events are complete, points for the medals are added up to decide the winner.

Game description from the publisher:

Wings of Glory is a game system that allows players to recreate aerial combat during World War I and II, using cards and miniatures to represent the airplanes and their maneuvers. In Wings of Glory players will control one or more airplanes, taking to the skies to engage their opponents in aerial duels, or trying to accomplish a specific mission, such as recon, escort, or bombing.

The Wings of Glory: WW1 Rules and Accessories Pack is a complete game system that includes all the rules and accessories necessary to play the WW1 version of the game system. Players will find the core WW1 rules system presented in a beautiful forty-page color booklet with Basic, Standard, Advanced, and a wealth of Optional rules. Also included are all the rules and counters necessary to use special models (such as multi-engine bombers and balloons) and special weapons (anti-aircraft, rockets and incendiary bullets).

The pack also features four decks of Damage Cards (A, B, C, D); Target, Trench, Machine Gun, Anti Aircraft Guns and Bomb cards; four airplane consoles; two rulers; and counters.

Airplane miniatures are not included; the pack must be combined with two or more WW1 Airplane Packs or Special Packs (each featuring a miniature and its maneuver deck), or with a WW1 Duel Pack.
